code-block-bg: true code-block-border-left: "#31BAE9" bibliography: references.bib --- ::: {.cell} ::: ## Introduction A few months into using `R` for data analysis, I had a lightbulb moment‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt actually know what `R` *was*. Sure, I could write some code and get results (output), but that didn‚Äôt mean I truly understood what `R` could *do* or how powerful it really is. I realized I never had a proper introduction to the language. Often, experts skip over details they assume are ‚Äòobvious‚Äô‚Äîbut things are only obvious once you're familiar with them. In my case, I felt like I‚Äôd been thrown into the deep end with `R`, missing the foundational understanding that would have made everything else click. Despite this rocky start, my passion to learn `R` didn‚Äôt wane. Over time, I‚Äôve come to see how much the way you‚Äôre introduced to `R` shapes your experience, especially if you‚Äôre used to point-and-click software (GUIs) and are now stepping into the world of command-line interfaces (CLIs) and scripting. That‚Äôs why, after navigating my own struggles, I decided to write this comprehensive guide. It‚Äôs meant for absolute beginners (and if the term ‚Äòabsolute beginner‚Äô feels a *little* harsh, I apologize‚Äîbut it answers the question: Who is this for?). I hope it will also help those who already have some `R` experience but feel like they missed out on key concepts during their own introductions to the language. I won‚Äôt promise that you‚Äôll become an `R` programming guru overnight after reading this guide, but by the end of it, you should be able to: - Install `R` and set up an IDE (Integrated Development Environment) to work in. - Run R commands and use the language with confidence. - Load and utilize `R` packages effectively. - Import data into the `R` environment. - Clean and manipulate data for more efficient analysis. - Understand basic data types and structures in `R`e.g., vectors, lists, and data frames. - Write your own R functions and scripts. - Use the power of `R` to perform some basic statistical analysis and data-processing tasks. - Appreciate the meaning of the following code: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} invisible( lapply( pkgs, library ) ) ``` ::: - Create beautiful graphs and visualizations to bring your data to life. - Know where to find additional help and resources to improve your `R` coding skills. ::: callout-tip To make this post more interactive, I‚Äôve enabled code execution right here within the post, so you don‚Äôt necessarily have to copy and paste it into your own IDE. You can run the code directly within the post, thanks to the [quarto-webR](https://github.com/coatless/quarto-webr) extension! I'll explain more about this later on. ::: ## Overview of `R` ### ***What is `R`?*** At first glance, "What is `R`?" may seem like a simple question, but as @zuur2009; point out, it‚Äôs not so easily answered‚Äîand I agree. Broadly defined, `R` is a computer language that allows users to program algorithms and use tools that others have developed. This is a fairly generalized description and could apply to the plethora of programming languages, but `R` stands out because it‚Äôs often defined as a powerful environment specifically designed for statistical computing and graphics‚Äîor more simply, a statistical programming language. It was developed by Ross Ihaka and Robert Gentleman as a free software environment for teaching, while they were colleagues at the University of Auckland in New Zealand [@vries2012a]. Their goal was to create an intuitive system for statistical computing and data visualization‚Äîsomething that statisticians across the world could adopt with ease. Given its origins, `R` is exceptionally well-suited for data science, a vital field in today‚Äôs world‚Äî developed by statisticians for statisticians. In fact, `R` is often referred to as the "lingua franca of statistics" among statisticians and scientists. A more practical way to understand `R`, however, is by looking at what it can *do*. As I‚Äôve often told colleagues and friends, ‚Äú**`R`** can do anything you can imagine,‚Äù and that‚Äôs hardly an exaggeration. With `R`, you can: - Write custom functions and perform calculations - Apply nearly every available statistical technique - Generate everything from simple to highly complex graphs - Perform geocomputation and geostatistics [@lovelace2019b] - Create stunning 3D visualizations [@rayshader] - Develop your own libraries of reusable functions Perhaps one of the most significant, nontrivial reasons for its widespread use is that `R` is free of charge, supported by a vast, active user community. *So Why Isn‚Äôt Everyone Using `R`?* This question is easier to answer: `R` has a notoriously steep learning curve. Since it relies heavily on programming, even though there are graphical user interfaces (GUIs) available, none are advanced enough to fully eliminate the need for coding. But once you get the hang of `R`, I reckon you‚Äôll find it hard to return to any other software for statistical computing. From my own experience‚Äîand from hearing others share theirs‚Äîlearning both `R` and statistics simultaneously can feel overwhelming, like climbing two steep hills at once. @zuur2009, also acknowledge this issue, noting that when `R` is taught alongside statistics, many learners tend to focus on simply getting the `R` code to run, and often overlooking the weightier statistical concepts behind it. I faced the same struggle when I was first introduced to `R`. That‚Äôs why this post focuses primarily on providing basic R instructions and not diving too deeply into statistics. However, I will demonstrate some fundamental statistical procedures you can perform in R later in the post. If your goal is to learn both R and statistics, this guide will provide the foundation you need to master R, equipping you with the skills to explore its powerful statistical tools and the vast range of packages that extend its capabilities. ### ***Historical Background of `R`*** `R` is a modern implementation, or dialect, of an earlier programming language called [S](https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-0-387-21856-4) [@becker2018]. It also incorporates lexical scoping semantics inspired by [Scheme](https://www.scheme.org/) The development of `R` began in 1991, when Professors Ross Ihaka and Robert Gentleman at the University of Auckland, New Zealand, recognized the need for a better software environment for their Macintosh teaching laboratory. Their journey into developing `R` is detailed in a 1996 paper in the *Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics* [@ihaka1996]. The name "`R`" is a nod to both the first names of its authors (Ross and Robert) and a playful reference to its predecessor, [S](https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-0-387-21856-4). By 1993, after they had made significant progress, Ihaka and Gentleman began to share their work more widely, distributing binary copies of `R` through the StatLib data archive and announcing it on the *s-news* mailing list. Interest in `R` quickly grew, and many began to collaborate with the duo‚Äîmost notably, Martin M√§chler from ETH Zurich. In June 1995, M√§chler convinced Ihaka and Gentleman to release `R` as free and open-source software under the terms of the [Free Software Foundation](http://www.gnu.org/)'s [GNU General Public License](https://www.r-project.org/COPYING), allowing anyone to use and modify it freely. Initially, bug reports were sent via email, but as interest surged, it became clear that manually maintaining communication was unsustainable. In response, in March 1996, M√§chler volunteered the facilities at ETH Zurich to set up the *r-testers* mailing list, which allowed for automated discussions about `R` and its development. Approximately a year later, *r-testers* was replaced by three newsgroups: *R-announce*, *R-help*, and *R-devel*. Over time, more mailing lists were added to accommodate the growing community. Currently, the `R` project maintains five general mailing lists, including *R-package-devel* and *R-packages*, which can be found at . Today, the R Core Team‚Äîa group of currently 18 active individuals‚Äîhas write access to the `R` source code (), guiding its ongoing development. Many others have also contributed through new code submissions and bug fixes, making R a true collaborative effort. For those interested in a more detailed account of R‚Äôs development, Ross Ihaka provides a fascinating overview, available at [http:// cran.r‚Äêproject.org/doc/html/ interface98‚Äêpaper/paper.html](https://cran.r-project.org/doc/html/interface98-paper/paper.html). The *Comprehensive R Archive Network* ([CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/mirrors.html)) was officially launched on 23 April 1997, providing a centralized platform to store R‚Äôs executable files, source code, documentation, and packages. Over time, [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/mirrors.html) has grown into one of the most extensive repositories for data science tools. In April 2003, the [R Foundation](https://www.r-project.org/foundation/) was founded as a non-profit organization to provide long-term support for `R`‚Äôs continued development, ensuring that it remains a leading tool for statistical computing and data visualization. Since its humble beginnings, `R` has grown into a global force in statistical computing and data science. Thanks to its open-source nature and a thriving community, it remains one of the most widely used and rapidly evolving tools for data analysis. As the field of data science expands, `R`‚Äôs importance continues to grow, cementing its place as an indispensable resource for statisticians, data scientists, and researchers alike. ## Getting Started With `R` Programming Every journey begins with gathering the right tools, and your adventure into `R` programming is no different. The first essential step for any `R` novice is setting up the environment to start coding. Essentially, you have two main options: 1. **Install [R](https://www.r-project.org/ "R") and an IDE such as [RStudio](https://www.rstudio.com/ "RStudio"), [VS Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/) or [Positron](https://github.com/posit-dev/positron)** 2. **Run R in a browser,** for example, via [RStudio Cloud](https://rstudio.cloud/ "RStudio Cloud"). Additionally, as I mentioned earlier, I‚Äôve enabled live code execution right here within the post, so you don‚Äôt need to copy and paste it into your own IDE. You can run the code directly within the post, courtesy of the [quarto-webR](https://github.com/coatless/quarto-webr) extension. While installing [**R**](https://www.r-project.org/ "R") along with an IDE like [**RStudio**](https://www.rstudio.com/ "RStudio"), [**VS Code**](https://code.visualstudio.com/)or [**Positron**](https://github.com/posit-dev/positron) requires a little more time and effort, it offers a more robust setup‚Äîallowing offline work and leveraging your computer‚Äôs CPU‚ÄîI highly recommend this approach, especially for those committed to diving deep into `R`. However, if you're just exploring or testing the waters, running `R` online through platforms like [RStudio Cloud](https://rstudio.cloud/ "RStudio Cloud") may be more convenient (provided you have a reliable internet connection). Whichever path you choose, this post is designed to accommodate you. Whether you install `R` locally or use an online platform, the examples and instructions provided here will guide you seamlessly through your `R` programming journey. ### *Downloading and Installing `R`* Now that we‚Äôve covered an overview of R and some of its history, it's time to get your own copy of R so you can start using it. The easiest way to do this is by downloading a precompiled binary distribution of R, which includes the base system and contributed packages, and installing it on your computer. While it's also possible to install [R from source](https://docs.posit.co/resources/install-r-source.html), this is more complex and generally not necessary for most users. I recommend sticking to the precompiled binaries, which are easy to install and are available for a range of operating systems, including Windows, macOS, and Linux. In this guide, we‚Äôll focus on installing R on Windows and macOS. #### Installing R on Windows Installing R on Windows is a straightforward process. Here's a step-by-step guide: 1. **Go to the [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/) website**: Visit the Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN) at . 2. **Download R for Windows**: Click on the "Download R for Windows" link. 3. **Download the base system**: On the next page, click "base" or "Install R for the first time" to download the R executable file (e.g., `R-4.x.x-win.exe`). 4. **Run the R installer**: Once downloaded, double-click the executable file to start the installation process. You may be prompted to allow the application to make changes to your device‚Äîclick "Yes" to continue. 5. **Select installation language**: The installer will first prompt you to select the installation language. Choose your preferred language and click "OK". ![](images/1-select_language.png){fig-align="center"} 6. **License agreement**: You‚Äôll see a window with the GNU General Public License information. Simply click "Next". ![](images/2-license.png){fig-align="center"} 7. **Choose the destination location**: By default, R will install in `C:\Program Files\R\R-4.x.x`. Unless you have a specific reason to change it, I recommend leaving this as is and clicking "Next". ![](images/3-directory.png){fig-align="center"} 8. **Select components**: In the "Select Components" window, the default options should suffice for most users, so just click "Next". ![](images/4-components.png){fig-align="center"} 9. **Startup options**: Again, leave the default startup options selected and click "Next". ![](images/5-startup_options.png){fig-align="center"} 10. **Select Start Menu folder**: The default Start Menu folder is fine, so just click "Next" here as well. ![](images/6-start_menu.png){fig-align="center"} 11. **Additional tasks**: The installer will ask if you'd like to create desktop shortcuts or add `R` to your system PATH. The default options are usually best, so leave them checked and click "Next". ![](images/7-additional_tasks.png){fig-align="center"} 12. **Begin installation**: After confirming all the settings, click "Next" to start the installation process. ![](images/8-installing.png){fig-align="center"} 13. **Complete installation**: Once the installation is complete, click "Finish" to close the installer. ![](images/9-completed.png){fig-align="center"} Congratulations, you've successfully installed `R` on your Windows system! #### Installing `R` on macOS The installation process for macOS is very similar to that of Windows, but with a few differences in file format. Follow these steps: 1. **Go to the [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/) website**: Head over to . 2. **Download `R` for macOS**: Click on "Download R for macOS". 3. **Choose the latest release**: In the "Latest release" section, download the appropriate version of `R` for your macOS system. ![](images/11-download_r_mac.png){fig-align="center"} 4. **Open the installer**: Once the download is complete, double-click the `.pkg` installer file to open it. 5. **Follow the installation prompts**: Click "Continue" and proceed through the installer by following the on-screen instructions. 6. **Complete installation**: Once the installation process finishes, click "Close" to exit the installer. You now have `R` installed on your macOS system! With these steps completed, you‚Äôre ready to start programming in `R`! Next, we‚Äôll move on to setting up a suitable Integrated Development Environment (IDE) to enhance your experience with `R`. ### *Exploring IDE Options for `R`: Elevate Your `R` Programming with RStudio, VS Code, or Positron* #### Getting Started With the `R` Interface When working with `R`, several user interfaces (UIs) are available, but every installation of `R` includes a basic/standard interface‚Äî sometimes called the "R Console." While you may eventually prefer using an advanced IDE like RStudio, it's important to familiarize yourself with this standard interface. Not only can it be helpful when using a machine without your preferred or favorite interfaces, but it also serves as a good foundation for understanding how other interfaces are organized. You may even come to appreciate and enjoy the simplicity of the standard interface. What follows is a practical guide on using the `RGUI`, which is the standard graphical interface for `R` on Windows platforms. On Windows, `R` is typically installed in **`C:\Program Files\R`**, and you can access it from the Start menu under the `R` group. If, during installation, you selected "Create a desktop shortcut," you‚Äôll also have an `RGUI` icon on your desktop. To launch `R`, simply double-click this icon, and you‚Äôll be greeted by a user interface that looks something like this: ![](images/13-rgui.png){fig-align="center"} When opened, the main window, labeled "R Console," will appear. This is where you will enter and execute your `R` commands. You can type commands directly into the Console and see the output immediately. This is also where error messages appear, . Keep in mind, closing the Console will end your `R` session. The main window of `RGUI` is the "R Console," which automatically opens when you launch `R`. This Console is where you enter `R` commands one at a time. Depending on the command, the output will be displayed in the Console, and this is also where any error messages will appear. The Console is unique and it's the primary space for interacting with `R`‚Äîkeep in mind, closing the Console will end your `R` session. ::: callout-note ## **Isn‚Äôt `R` a Language?** You might hear me refer to `R` as if it were a person, saying things like ‚ÄúTell `R` to do this‚Äù or ‚ÄúTell `R` to do that.‚Äù But, of course, `R` can‚Äôt *do* anything‚Äîit‚Äôs just a language. This is simply shorthand for saying, ‚ÄúInstruct your computer to perform a task by writing a command in the `R` language in the R console.‚Äù It‚Äôs your computer, not `R` itself, that does the heavy lifting. Is this shorthand a bit imprecise and lazy? Yes. But does everyone still use it? Absolutely‚Äîbecause it's convenient and saves time! ::: For new users, the easiest way to save the Console‚Äôs contents is to navigate to **File** ‚Üí **Save to file** from the menu. However, note that the Console only retains the last few thousand lines written to it, so it's wise to save important work elsewhere. You may also find it helpful to clear the Console to start fresh. To do this, simply press `Ctrl + L` or select **Edit** ‚Üí **Clear console** from the menu. *Ready to Write Your First Program in `R`?* Now that we have `R` installed and running, let‚Äôs dive right in by writing our first simple computer program. To do this, open `R` (if it‚Äôs not already open), and in the "R Console" type the following code after the `>` prompt symbol, then press **Enter**: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} print("Hello, World!") ``` ::: After pressing **Enter**, you should see the following output appear in the Console, as shown in the image below. ![](images/14-hello_world.png){fig-align="center"} Congratulations!‚Äîyou‚Äôve just written a computer program! A computer program is simply a sequence of instructions that perform a specific task when executed by the computer. The "Hello, World!" program is a classic way to introduce novice programmers to a new language. It serves two purposes: demonstrating the basic syntax of the language and verifying that the installation was successful, ensuring you know how to use it. In this case, the program consists of just one instruction‚Äîthe command to display the text "Hello, World!" in the console. The command responsible for this is `print()`. *A couple of things to note about your first program:* - **"Hello, World!" is a *string***: A string is a way of representing text in a computer program. In `R`, a string must be enclosed in quotes (`' '` or `" "`), which act as delimiters, signaling where the string starts and ends. The text inside the quotes‚Äî`Hello, World!`‚Äîis the actual string. - **`print` is a *function***: Just like in mathematics, a function in `R` takes input, performs an operation, and returns output. The `print` function‚Äôs job is to take its input (in this case, the string `"Hello, World!"`) and display it in the console in a readable format. - **Calling a function**: To execute the function, you need to "call" it, which is done by following the function name (`print`) with a pair of parentheses. The input to the function, in this case, the string, goes inside the parentheses. The parentheses are important as they tell `R` where the input starts and ends, serving as another type of delimiter. Let‚Äôs try another simple program with a basic arithmetic calculation‚Äîyes, `R` can function like a calculator. You can: - Add numbers with `+` - Subtract with `-` - Multiply with `*` - Divide with `/` - Raise numbers to a power with `^` Type the following code into the console and press **Enter**: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} print(4 + 2) ``` ::: After pressing **Enter**, you should see the following output in the console: ![](images/15-arithmetic_program.png){fig-align="center"} So far, we've been using the `print()` function to display output. However, you can actually get output in the console without explicitly calling `print()`. You don‚Äôt always need the `print()` function for simple outputs. Typing just the expression will display the result:. For example, suppose you type: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} "Hello, World!" ``` ::: In the console, you‚Äôll see the following result: ![](images/16-Hello_world_2.png){fig-align="center"} Similarly, you can try: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} 2 + 2 ``` ::: with the output: ![](images/17-arithmetic_program_2.png){fig-align="center"} ::: callout-important ## **Read-Evaluate-Print Loop (REPL)** So far, you‚Äôve been using `R` in what computer scientists call *interactive mode*. This means you type a command into the console, R immediately reads it, evaluates it, and prints the result back to the console for you to see. Then, you type the next command, and the process repeats. This cycle is known as the *Read-Evaluate-Print Loop*, or REPL for short. `R`, like other interactive languages, excels at providing immediate feedback, which makes it especially useful for statisticians and data analysts who often run small procedures, check results, and refine their approach iteratively‚Äîafter all, R was originally designed by statisticians, for statisticians. As beginners, the REPL offers a fantastic way to observe `R`‚Äôs behavior and receive instant feedback on the simple programs we‚Äôre writing, helping us quickly understand how R processes our commands. ::: ::: callout-tip ## **When Do We Compile?** In some languages, like C, Java, or FORTRAN, you need to *compile* your human-readable code into machine-readable code (typically in the form of 1s and 0s) before it can be executed. If you've worked with those languages before, you might wonder whether you need to compile your R code too. The answer is no‚ÄîR is a dynamic programming language, meaning it automatically *interprets* your code on the fly as you run it, without the need for a separate compilation step. ::: *The "R Editor" Window:* For more complex programs, you'll want to work in the "R Editor," where you can write and edit multiple lines of code. When you're ready to move beyond typing and executing commands one by one, you can use the "R Editor" window to write and manage scripts efficiently. To open a blank editor, click **File** ‚Üí **New Script** from the menu. If you have an existing script, select **File** ‚Üí **Open Script** to continue working on it. The image below shows a new blank "R Editor" window. ![](images/18-R_editor.png){fig-align="center"} You can have multiple "R Editor" windows open simultaneously, allowing you to work on different scripts side by side. ::: callout-note The available menus and toolbar options change based on which window is currently in focus. In the image above, the focus has shifted from the "R Console" to the "R Editor," which is why the toolbar and menu options have updated accordingly. ::: As expected, the script editor allows you to run commands either individually or in groups. You can also execute part of an expression by highlighting the code and pressing `Ctrl + R` (or using the "Run line or selection" button in the toolbar, or clicking **Edit** ‚Üí **Run line or selection**¬†from the menu). - To run a single line of code, place the cursor within the line you want to execute and press `Ctrl + R`. Note that one line may not always be a complete executable statement. - To run a specific section of code, highlight the desired text and press `Ctrl + R`. The highlighted text can span multiple lines or just part of one. - To run the entire script, highlight everything using `Ctrl + A` and then press `Ctrl + R`. You can save your script anytime by pressing `Ctrl + S` or selecting **File** ‚Üí **Save**. *The "R Graphics" Window:* When you utilize a function such as `plot()` to create a graphic, the graphics window‚Äîcommonly referred to as the "device"‚Äîserves as the default output area. If a graphics window is not already open, a new one is produced, otherwise the existing window is reused. To illustrate this, let‚Äôs plot a graph using a built-in dataset called **`pressure`**. The dataset, which comes pre-installed with `R`, shows the relationship between temperature (in degrees Celsius) and vapor pressure of mercury (measured in millimeters). Below, we apply the `plot()` function to the pressure dataset and execute it from the "R Editor": ![](images/19-R_graphics.png){fig-align="center"} To open a new graphics window without closing an existing one, you can use the `dev.new()` function. This allows you to create multiple graphics windows for your visualizations. To save a graphic, simply click **File** ‚Üí **Save As** and select your desired format from the menu. *The "Data Editor" Window:* The simplest way to examine the contents of a basic data object is by printing it directly to the Console. Just type the object's name at the command prompt. To explore the data within a data frame or matrix, you can use either `fix(dataframe)` or `View(dataframe)`, where "dataframe" refers to the name of your data object. These functions are specifically for data frames and matrices. The `fix()` function allows you to modify the data, while `View()` only displays it without editing capabilities. Alternatively, you can navigate to **Edit** ‚Üí **Data Editor** in the menu and specify the name of the data frame or matrix you wish to edit. As an example, let's view the **pressure** dataset we used earlier to plot the graph. You can use the following command: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} fix(pressure) ``` ::: ![](images/20-R_data_editor.png){fig-align="center"} This will open the data frame in a tab where you can inspect it interactively. Any changes you make using the Data Editor are automatically saved to your workspace (you‚Äôll learn more about saving the workspace later). However, while the Data Editor is open, you cannot run any other code, and files cannot be saved directly from this window. *The "R History" Window:* You can access your command history by using the `history()` function, which opens a window displaying your most recent commands. By default, this shows the last 25 lines of code you've submitted. Below is an example of what my current history looks like. ![](images/21-history.png){fig-align="center"} To save the contents of this history window, you can either click **File** ‚Üí **Save to file** in the menu or use the `savehistory()` function directly in the Console. This allows you to preserve your previous commands for future reference or reuse. *Saving the Workspace* R stores the data and objects you're working with in an area of your computer's memory called the "workspace." While the standard R interface doesn't have a dedicated window to display these objects, you can easily list them in the Console by using the `ls()` function. These objects can include data imported from external sources (such as text files), new data you've generated, results from expressions you've executed, and various other elements. When you shut down R, it will typically prompt you to save your workspace. If you choose to save it under the default name `.RData` (note that it's just the file extension with no filename), `R` will automatically load this workspace the next time you launch it. For substantial work, it's generally considered good practice to save your raw data sources and a script that recreates your data objects. This ensures that you‚Äîor anyone else‚Äîcan fully reproduce your analysis. From this perspective, it's often unnecessary to save the workspace itself. However, if your work involves lengthy data processing or a complex script, saving the workspace can be useful as it provides a convenient starting point for your next session, saving time and effort. To save your workspace, either click **File** ‚Üí **Save workspace** in the menu, or use the `save.image()` function in the Console. If you want to save it under a specific filename, use `save(file = "filename")`. You can load a previously saved workspace by running `load(file = "filename")`. So far, we‚Äôve successfully interacted with base `R`‚Äîwe‚Äôve written our first "Hello, World!" program, performed basic arithmetic, and even plotted a graph (how cool is that?). While `RGUI` is functional, it can feel somewhat basic and limited compared to modern integrated development environments (IDEs), which offer enhanced features for coding, debugging, and data visualization. In the next section, we will explore the powerful capabilities provided by IDEs. #### RStudio IDE for `R` and Python One of the most popular ways to interface with `R`, beyond the basic `RGUI`, is through RStudio, a powerful Integrated Development Environment (IDE) designed primarily for `R`. RStudio offers an intuitive and interactive environment, making coding, data analysis, and project management significantly easier. However, it‚Äôs important to note that before using RStudio, you must first install `R` on your computer. According to RStudio‚Äôs mission statement: > *‚ÄúTo create free and open-source software for data science, scientific research, and technical communication. Although we primarily focus on static 2D plots in this guide, which are most useful for assignments, theses, or publications, it‚Äôs good to know that RStudio has the capacity to handle more complex and interactive visualizations. ##### Working Directories and Starting your `R` Projects in RStudio Once you‚Äôve successfully installed R, a common challenge arises when you need to import data from your local drive or save output like plots back to your computer. You might find yourself asking, "Where is my data located?" or "Where did R save my plot?" This is where **working directories** come into play. In simple terms, a working directory is a folder on your computer where R reads and writes files. When you first install R, it assigns a **default working directory**, which is usually the "Documents" folder on your system (`C:/Users/YourName/Documents` on Windows). This means that unless you specify otherwise, `R` will save your files or try to find your data in this default location. As soon as R is installed and you start working with it, you might notice that several system files get created in the home directory (your "Documents" folder): - **`.RData`** - **`.Rhistory`** - **`.Rprofile`** - **`.Renviron`** **`.RData`:** This file saves the current workspace, including all objects, variables, and functions you‚Äôve defined in your R session. When you quit R, you may be prompted with the option to "Save workspace image?" If you choose to save, R will create or update the `.RData` file. The next time you open R in that directory, it will reload the objects saved in this file, restoring your previous session. While this file can be useful for quickly returning to a prior session, it may become cumbersome as your work evolves, so advanced users often turn off the automatic saving of `.RData` to avoid potential conflicts or confusion between sessions. ::: callout-tip To manage your R environment and ensure reproducibility across projects, it‚Äôs a good idea to adjust a few default settings in RStudio. Navigate to `Tools` ‚Üí `Global Options`, and in the **General** tab under **Basic**, you‚Äôll see options that start with `Restore`. While it may seem counter-intuitive at first not to restore everything as you left it, making these changes will greatly improve the reproducibility of your projects. Here‚Äôs what I recommend unchecking: - **Restore most recently opened project at startup** - **Restore previously open source documents at startup** - **Restore .RData into workspace at startup** Next, in the same **General** tab under **Workspace**, set `Save workspace to .RData on exit` to **Never**. While it might seem useful to save your workspace between sessions, in practice, this can lead to unexpected issues down the line. Starting each session with a clean workspace minimizes confusion and ensures that your projects remain independent and reproducible. These changes aren‚Äôt mandatory‚Äîyou can always adjust them later once you better understand their importance. But implementing them early can save you many headaches as you progress in `R`. ::: **`.Rhistory`:** This file stores the history of all the commands you've entered in the R console. It allows you to recall past commands easily, making it a helpful tool for navigating through previous work. You can access your command history using the **`history()`** function or by scrolling through past commands using the up and down arrow keys. **`.Rprofile`:** The `.Rprofile` file allows users to customize the behavior of `R` at startup. This file is written in `R` code and can contain settings and options to modify your `R` environment. For instance, you might use it to set a preferred working directory or automatically load packages you frequently use. There are two levels of `.Rprofile` files: - **User-level**: Found in your home directory (e.g., `~/.Rprofile`), it applies to all R sessions. - **Project-level**: Located in specific project folders, it only applies to R sessions opened in that project. If both user-level and project-level `.Rprofile` files exist, R will only source one, unless you explicitly include the user-level `.Rprofile` in the project-level file using: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} source("~/.Rprofile") ``` ::: You can edit your `.Rprofile` using the function `usethis::edit_r_profile()` in R. **`.Renviron`:** Similar to `.Rprofile`, the `.Renviron` file allows you to define **environment variables**. These variables can be used to store information like API keys or credentials that you don‚Äôt want to hard-code into your scripts for security reasons. The `.Renviron` file follows a simple key-value format: ``` makefile KEY1=value1 KEY2=value2 ``` You can retrieve environment variables during your R session using `Sys.getenv("KEY1")`, which will return `"value1"`. Like `.Rprofile`, `.Renviron` can exist at both the user and project level, but only one will be sourced. To edit your `.Renviron` file, you can use the `usethis::edit_r_environ()` function. The current working directory is displayed by the RStudio IDE within the title region of the Console pane. You can also check your current working directory by running the command `getwd()` in the console to print it out. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} getwd() ``` ::: If you‚Äôre not using RStudio Projects, you‚Äôll need to manually set the working directory at the start of every R script using the `setwd()` function, like so: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} setwd("C:/Users/Elias Nelson Kaunda/Documents/Intro-to-R") ``` ::: The code above sets the working directory to the "`Intro-to-R`" folder, meaning to say when loading data R will start looking from this directory. In the code above, you're telling R to use the "`Intro-to-R`" folder as the working directory. Any files you read or save will be handled within this directory. However, there's a catch: **`setwd()` uses an absolute file path**, which is specific to your computer's directory structure. If you share your script with someone else or switch to a different computer, the path won‚Äôt work unless their folder structure matches yours exactly (you are unlikely to have a directory structure `"C:/Users/Elias Nelson Kaunda/Documents/Intro-to-R"` on your computer). This limits the portability and reproducibility of your project. RStudio provides a solution to this problem through **R Projects** (files with the `.Rproj` extension). Using RStudio projects eliminates so much of the early-stage hassle and confusion around reading in and exporting data. When you create an R Project, RStudio sets the working directory to the folder containing the project file. This allows you to use **relative paths** within the project, making it much easier to share your work and collaborate with others. For example, if you need to send your analysis to a colleague, you can simply share the entire project folder. Your colleague can open the `.Rproj` file in RStudio, and any script that references files using relative paths will run smoothly‚Äîwithout needing to alter the working directory.R Projects offer several key benefits: - **File Organization**: All the files you generate‚Äîdata, scripts, plots, reports‚Äîare stored in the same folder. This keeps your work organized without the need to manually manage file locations. - **Reproducibility**: Since R Projects use relative paths, sharing your project folder ensures that others can reproduce your analysis without needing to modify file paths. - **Version Control**: R Projects integrate seamlessly with GitHub, allowing you to use version control to track changes to your code over time. This is especially useful for collaboration or when you need to roll back to a previous version of your analysis. - **Convenience**: You don‚Äôt need to worry about setting the working directory manually. RStudio automatically uses the project folder as the root directory. Here‚Äôs how you can create a new R Project in RStudio: 1. This setup ensures that all your scripts, data, and output are stored together in one place.
